items.content:
frontend focus

#â€‹603 â€” July 26, 2023 | Read on the web

Core Web Vitals for Search Engine Optimization: What Do We Need to Know? â€” Harry aims to clear up any misunderstandings around core web vitals metrics and how they might impactÂ SEO. A well-sourcedÂ article.

Harry Roberts

Legibility: How and Why Typography Affects Ease of Reading â€” A free seven chapter book from a typographic expert covering letter spacing, alignment, layout, rendering, aesthetics, and much more. An excellent resource on typographic variables thatâ€™s well worth a read for getting up to speed on all things legibility, readability andÂ usability.

Get a Complete Picture of Your Siteâ€™s Performance â€” Track Core Web Vitals and learn how users experience the speed of your site. Use Lighthouse audits to fix issues. Measure the impact of slowdowns on business metrics and user engagement. Integrate with your CI/CD process to stayÂ fast.

SpeedCurve sponsor

The Arc Browser Reaches v1.0 â€” Iâ€™ve seen plenty of folks advocating for this new Chromium-powered browser â€”Â and now, following a period of being invite only, it's finally publicly downloadable as a 1.0 release. (Release notesÂ here)

The Browser Company

Google's 'Web Environment Integrity' Draft Draws Developer Ire â€” This is a developing story worth keeping an eye on. Google has proposed an idea called Web Environment Integrity (WEI) as a way for clients to establish their â€˜integrityâ€™ with a server by way of a third party. â€œIn simpler terms, WEI provides a way for a browser to prove it is working as a website operator expects, and hasnâ€™t been manipulated.â€ Unsurprisingly, many folks see where this couldÂ lead..

The Register

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • The folks at Devographics (the team behind the State of CSS) want your help in shaping the very first 'State of HTML' survey.

  • The third edition of the PNG spec has been published as a W3C WorkingÂ Draft.

  • The No CSS Club is, unsurprisingly, a collection of sites that use no CSS at all. Don't expect anything pretty, but they're certainlyÂ fast.

  • Cloudflare's Radar Domain Rankings now track global trendingÂ domains.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

â–¶Â Â DX in the Frontend Developer Ecosystem â€” A half-hour talk about frontend trends, new tools, and browser features, asking if weâ€™re all busy reinventing the wheel for a reason or if sites built â€˜yesterdayâ€™ may be as a good as those on the cuttingÂ edge.

Stefan Judis

Scroll Driven Animations in CSS are a Joy to Play Around With â€” A look at some of the fun we can have with scroll driven animations â€” giving us the chance to animate elements based on a scroll instead of time. This post looks at the basics, shares some ideas, and neatÂ demos.

Brecht De Ruyte

Server-Side Rendering Is Having a Moment - by Sentry â€” Server-side rendering-supported frameworks like Next.js are buzzing. But can they make blazing fast web apps? ReadÂ on.

Sentry sponsor

Recreating YouTubeâ€™s Ambient Mode Glow Effect â€” A look at how a little Canvas and requestAnimationFrame can come together to create that subtle glowing effect you see around YouTubeÂ videos.

Adrian Bece

WebGPU: The Cross-Platform Graphics API of Tomorrow? â€” Learn how to build an app with WebGPU (using C++) for the web and specificÂ platforms.

FranÃ§ois Beaufort

How to Use CSS object-fit and object-position â€” Learn how to use CSS object-fit to determine how images fit within a given space, and how to position those images with object-position.

Ralph Mason

Can We Query the Root Container? â€” The complexities of containment, overflow, and â€˜propagationâ€™.

Miriam Suzanne

Easy SVG Sparklines â€” With just a little SVG you can easily create sparkline charts thatâ€™ll render in the browser and donâ€™t require any JavaScript atÂ all.

Alex Plescan

The Rise of JPEG XL: Apple's Support and Image CompressionÂ Insights â€” On the significance of Appleâ€™s support for JPEG XL and what this means for the widespread adoption of this next-generation image compressionÂ format.

JON SNEYERS

Designing for Accessibility: Creating Inclusive and User-Centric Products
StÃ©phanie Walter

The Problem with Auto-Generated Alternative Texts for Images
Daniela Kubesch

Tailwind CSS Tips and Tricks Worth Knowing
Yoav Ganbar

ğŸ›¸ Emerge Tools

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

TOAST UI Grid: A Customizable Grid Control for the Web â€” A powerful MIT-licensed grid-style control for the display, editing, and management of data. It comes from the same folks as TUI Editor and TUI Calendar and while itâ€™s happy on its own, there are wrappers for Vue and React too. GitHubÂ repo.

NHN

wavesurfer.js 7: Audio Waveform Player â€” If youâ€™re creating a podcast player, audio experience, or anything where seeing an interactive audio waveform could be useful, check this out. GitHubÂ repo.

katspaugh and contributors

You Look Like You Could Use a T-Shirt. And a Better AuthÂ Provider â€” Spin up a local instance of FusionAuth in just 5 minutes. Send us a screenshot and weâ€™ll send you a t-shirt. It'sÂ free.

FusionAuth sponsor

Detect Scroll: A Fast, Light JS Module for Detecting Scroll Activity â€” Expands on the browserâ€™s limited scroll event listener to allow you to accurately detect direction and location on bothÂ axes.

Jordan Egstad

Winded: A Tool to Test Responsive Designs in Different Viewport Sizes Simultaneously â€” Created for Tailwind sites (hence the name) but useful for testing any responsive design. Scanning multiple device sizes at a glance is a niceÂ feature.

Winded

Tabler Icons: Over 4500 Vector Icons for the Web â€” Open source icons you can use by either copying or downloading SVGs or PNGs or use one of the helper libraries like @tabler/icons-react to take them direct into a React app,Â say.

Tabler

React Tweet: A Fresh Way to Embed Tweets in a React App â€” Vercel has come up with an elegant way to embed posts from the site formerly known as Twitter that's faster and smaller than the official mechanism and supports React Server Components and â€˜any React framework.â€™ Now let's just hope Elon doesnâ€™t turn off theÂ taps..

Vercel

items.content:
#â€‹602 â€” July 19, 2023 | Read on the web

What Is Page Bloat? And How Is It Hurting Your Search Rank and Users? â€” A thorough bit of research into how the Web's pages have only continued to grow (complete with images, video, JavaScript, etc.), why this bloat is bad, and how to track and fight its upwardÂ creep.

Tammy Everts

Writing CSS in 2023: Is It Any Different to a Few Years Ago? â€” Yep, CSS is evolving faster than ever. So. with all these new features, and more on the way, how we write CSS is naturally evolving, too. Here, Geoff shares which features have had the most influence on his current approaches toÂ CSS (no Tailwind here,Â surprisingly).

Geoff Graham (Smashing Magazine)

The Leading API Platform for Building and Using APIs â€” Get access to a wide range of features for API testing, documentation, collaboration, mocking, and more. Automate repetitive tasks, stay organized, and build robust workflows to ensure your APIs remain reliable andÂ performant.

Postman sponsor

ğŸ™‚ Using Emoji on the Web â€” It was World Emoji Day earlier this week (yes, thatâ€™s a thing) so hereâ€™s a good look at using them on the web: â€œprobably more than you ever wanted to know aboutÂ emojiâ€.

Ollie Williams

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • You can now test and experiment with WordPress directly in the browser thanks to the new WordPress Playground. This uses more Web magic than you might think: PHP runs as a WebAssembly binary, as does SQLite, and a service worker plays the role of Web server.

  • Wix is launching an AI tool to to create 'entire websites' via prompts.

  • Fancy playing Wordle directly from the browser address bar? It's possible.

  • Calibri is out and Aptos is in as Microsoft's new default font.

  • You'll need to squint a bit, but the raw data from Mozilla's benchmarks seems to show Firefox passing Chromium performance wise in recent weeks?

  • Congrats to Hidde de Vries who is now a member of the CSS WorkingÂ Group.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

â–¶Â Â Getting Started with CSS Nesting â€” Native nesting support is now available in all major browsers, as such Kevin shares a thorough look at it. A good resource to get you started using this new tool to increase the modularity and maintainability of yourÂ CSS.

Kevin Powell

CSS Findings from the Threads App â€” Ahmad goes spelunking through Metaâ€™s new Threads app to see what interesting CSS findings can be gleaned â€”Â such as them using CSS Grid for the postÂ layout.

Ahmad Shadeed

The 2023 State of the API Report is Here â€” The State of the API is the world's largest survey and report on APIs, with findings from over 40K developers and APIÂ professionals.

Postman sponsor

A Case Study on Scroll-Driven Animation Performance â€” A look at how a new set of browser APIs to natively support scroll-driven animations are making for a much smoother experience compared to the classic way of implementingÂ them.

Yuriko Hirota

Three Common Types of Test Automation â€” Explores how to plan the right strategy for testing via two general testing modes and three common types of testÂ automation.

Ramona Schwering

â–¶Â Â Advanced Positioning in CSS Grid â€” A practical, in-depth guide to positioning elements on CSS Grid exactly as you want â€” Covers how grid-row and grid-column work inÂ detail.

Zoran Jambor

Visually Hidden Links with 0 Dimensions â€” Ever wondered why visually-hidden links have a height/weight thatâ€™s set 1px? Manuel shares the reasonÂ whyâ€¦

Manuel MatuzoviÄ‡

Creating an Animated SVG Logo â€” A quick look at how to achieve a nice animated logo - the end result here isÂ slick.

Anthony Fu

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Flexer: A CSS Flexbox Playground â€” You probably donâ€™t need another Flexbox playground but this one is simple and has an interesting feature: You can select â€œActualâ€ (for the literal property names) or â€œSimplifiedâ€ (which is good for betterÂ understanding).

Idan Ram

Driver.js: Tours, Highlights, Contextual Help, and More â€” A no-dependency, vanilla JavaScript library for putting together on-page tours and contextual help systems. There are lots of examples to check out â€“ itâ€™s reallyÂ smooth.

Kamran Ahmed

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor
